page.title: 04DAIRY FARMING IN HALTON
page.content: Mr. P. E. Odlin gets approximately 234 litres a day from his 16 British Friesian dairy cows. Some are known by a number, while others have names such as Sally, Wendy, Betty, Daisy, Claire, Hazel and Damsel. The cows are milked individually by modern milking machines, which takes about 5 minutes for each cow night and morning. The milk is stored in a bulk tank, and a bulk tanker lorry comes daily to collect the milk for the Lincoln Co-op. The cows are fed on grass from the middle of April to the end of October, and indoors on hay in the winter, and they also eat dairy cake while being milked. The cows have to be watched for signs of milk fever just after calving, and also for mastitis, because then the milk can't be sold.
